title: R42445
content: The most recent multi-year authorization for federal surface transportation programs, SAFETEA-LU, expired in 2009. Since then, programs have operated on extensions due to constrained financial resources. The highway trust fund, funded by gasoline and diesel taxes, has declined, leading to debates on passing a bill without cutting spending, raising taxes, or increasing the deficit. Alternative finance and tolling are also key issues in the ongoing debate. The debate on passing a multi-year bill for federal surface transportation programs without cutting spending, raising taxes, or increasing the deficit continues. Other issues being discussed include alternative finance, tolling, public-private partnerships, project delivery acceleration, and performance management. The question of equity in federal spending distribution among states remains unresolved due to forecasted revenue constraints. The Senate passed MAP-21 in 2012 to reauthorize surface transportation programs for two years. The Senate passed MAP-21 in 2012, reauthorizing surface transportation programs for two years. The House committees reported favorably on H.R. 7, a five-year bill with a total authorization of $260 billion, linking transportation reauthorization with provisions for oil and gas production. Both bills reduce programs by two-thirds and do not have earmarks. The House passed the Surface Transportation Extension Act of 2012, Part II (H.R. 4348) to extend surface transportation authorizations through the end of FY2012. It includes provisions for the Keystone XL Pipeline, Gulf Coast Restoration Trust Fund, Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund guarantee, Coal Residuals Reuse and Management Act, and environmental streamlining from H.R. 7. The Senate later replaced this language with MAP-21, leading to a conference between the House and Senate. The Senate replaced the House-passed language from H.R. 4348 with MAP-21, enabling a conference between the two chambers. Transportation and Infrastructure Committee Chairman John Mica plans to negotiate the entire substance of H.R. 7 in the conference. Surface transportation reauthorization involves multiple committees and funding sources, with the highway trust fund primarily financed by excise taxes on motor fuels. The highway trust fund is primarily financed by excise taxes on motor fuels, with 90% of revenue coming from gasoline and diesel taxes. The fund consists of separate accounts for highways and mass transit, with fuel tax rates last raised in 1993. Due to economic factors and improved fuel efficiency, fuel tax revenues have fallen below projections, requiring transfers from the general fund to cover expenses. The economic downturn since 2007 and increased vehicle fuel efficiency have led to a decrease in fuel tax revenues, causing a shortfall in the highway trust fund. The Congressional Budget Office projects a shortfall of $4.6 billion by the end of FY2013, with a gap of $8-9 billion per year through FY2022. The mass transit account is also facing deficits, with a projected shortfall of $1.2 billion by the end of FY2014. This poses challenges for reauthorization legislation. The mass transit account, which received a $4.8 billion general fund transfer in FY2010, will remain above zero through FY2013 but then fall to a negative $1.2 billion shortfall by the end of FY2014.
